item.title: Inverse of a Matrix & Factorization into $A=LU$
item.description: 3.1 Inverse of a Matrix & Factorization into $A=LU$ Given a square matrix $A$, $A^{-1}$ is it’s inverse if $AA^{-1} = A^{-1}A = I$, where $I$ is the Identity Matrix and we say that $A$ is invertible or nonsingular. For a singular matrix $A$, the inverse does not exist and it’s determinant is $0$. Also, we can find a vector $x$ such that $Ax=0$. This means that one or more than one columns of $A$ is linear combination of other columns.
